title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress finds that there are over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs, some of which have duplicative or burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery. Streamlining these procedures will improve services to the public. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include Director (Director of the Office of Management and Budget), Federal agency (defined under section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code), Federal financial assistance (defined in section 7501(a)(5) of title 31, United States Code), local government (political subdivision of a State), and non-Federal entity (State, local government, or nonprofit organization). Local government is a political subdivision of a State, while a non-Federal entity refers to a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. A nonprofit organization is operated for public interest purposes, not for profit, and uses proceeds to maintain its operations. A nonprofit organization is operated primarily for scientific, educational, charitable, or similar purposes in the public interest, not for profit, and uses net proceeds to maintain, improve, or expand its operations. The term "State" includes various entities within the United States, while "tribal government" refers to an Indian tribe. The curr_chunk defines terms such as "Tribal government" as an Indian tribe and "Uniform administrative rule" as a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple Federal assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, and allow electronic application and reporting for Federal financial assistance programs. The Act requires agencies to designate a lead official, allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs, ensure timely and high-quality information, and set annual goals to measure performance. The Act mandates agencies to set annual goals to measure performance and report noncompliance reasons to Congress for possible extensions. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for comment. Each agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for comment and consultation with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation. Public forums on the plan are encouraged, and consultation with State, local, and tribal governments is required. The Director may extend the plan development period for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months after consulting with relevant committees. Each Federal agency must submit their plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. The Director is responsible for specific duties. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application for multiple programs and electronic processes for managing funding. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall establish a common system for applying, managing, and reporting on funding from multiple Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes electronic processes and uniform administrative rules across different Federal agencies to streamline procedures and improve coordination. The Director may designate a lead agency to streamline Federal financial assistance administrative procedures, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance the quality of information received from recipients. The Director may designate a lead agency to assist in improving the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies must submit information for review regarding their implementation of the Act, and exemptions may be granted if a Federal agency has few financial assistance programs. The Director may exempt Federal agencies from the Act's requirements if they have few financial assistance programs. A list of exempted agencies will be available to the public. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government. The Director will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, including making specific recommendations for implementation, evaluating agency performance, and assessing coordination among different levels of government and organizations. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather information for reviewing financial integrity or service quality of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

No judicial review allowed for compliance with the Act. No rights enforceable through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET. SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

The Act will take effect upon enactment and expire five years later.
